Title: Nagpur
Short description: Nagpur (formerly Nagpore) is the third largest city and winter capital of the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is the 13th largest Indian city by population

Title: Pune
Short description: Pune is considered to be the cultural capital of Maharashtra. It is also known as the "Oxford of the East" due to the presence of several well-known educational institutions

Title: Ahmedabad
Short description: Ahmedabad is the largest city and former capital of the Indian state of Gujarat. Cricket is a popular sport in Ahmedabad, which houses the 54,000-seat Sardar Patel Stadium

Title: Surat
Short description: Surat is a city in the Indian state of Gujarat. It used to be a large seaport and is now a center for diamond cutting and polishing.

Title: Jind
Short description: One of the first Sikh Kingdoms, Jind lies in the heart of Haryana and is the fourth district of the Jat belt

Title: Kanpur
Short description: Kanpur (formerly Cawnpore) is a large city in the state of Uttar Pradesh. The city is famous for its leather and textile industries.

Title: Amroha
Short description: Amroha Lok Sabha constituency is one of the 80 Lok Sabha (parliamentary) constituencies in Uttar Pradesh.
Image caption: Amroha Uttar Pradesh, India Children on camels in front of Azakhana

Title: Mangalore
Short description: Mangalore, officially known as Mangaluru, is the chief port city of the Indian state of Karnataka. It is the only city in Karnataka to have all modes of transport — Air, Road, Rail and Sea

Title: Tuticorin
Short description: Tuticorin, officially known as Thoothukudi, is a port city and an industrial city in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. The major harbour of Thoothukudi is well known as a pearl diving and fishing centre.

Title: Cape Town
Short description: Cape Town is the oldest city in South Africa, colloquially named the Mother City.

Title: Colombo
Short description: Colombo is the commercial capital and largest city of Sri Lanka by population.
Image caption: The Seema Malakaya of the Gangarama Temple

Title: Christ church
Short description: Christchurch is the largest city in the South Island of New Zealand and the seat of the Canterbury Region.
Image caption: New Brighton and the Port Hills, Christchurch, New Zealand

Title: Dubbo
Short description: Dubbo is a city in the Orana Region of New South Wales, Australia.
Image caption: Overlooking Dubbo from the suburb of West Dubbo

Title: Sydney
Short description: Sydney is the state capital of New South Wales and the most populous city in Australia and Oceania.

Title: Jamaica
Short description: Jamaica is an island country situated in the Caribbean Sea.

Title: Lahore
Short description: Lahore is the largest city in Pakistan and historic cultural centre of the Punjab region.

Title: Transvaal
Short description: The Province of the Transvaal (Afrikaans: Provinsie van die Transvaal), commonly referred to as the Transvaal, was a province of South Africa from 1910 until the end of apartheid in 1994, when a new constitution subdivided it.
Image caption: Coat of Arms of the South African Republic, and later, the Transvaal Province.

Title: Tauranga
Short description: Tauranga is the most populous city in the Bay of Plenty region of the North Island of New Zealand. It was settled by Māori late in the 13th century and by Europeans in the early 19th century and was constituted as a city in 1963.

Title: Taunton
Short description: Taunton is a large regional town in Somerset, England. The town's population in 2011 was 69,570. Taunton has over 1,000 years of religious and military history.
Image caption: The War Memorial and town centre, Taunton

Title: Ranji trophy
Short description: The Ranji Trophy is a domestic first-class cricket championship played in India between teams representing regional and state cricket associations. The competition currently consists of 37 teams, with all 29 states in India and two of the seven union territories having at least one representation. The competition is named after first Indian cricketer who played international cricket, Ranjitsinhji, who was also known as 'Ranji
Image caption: The logo for Paytm Ranji Trophy

Title: Deodhar trophy
Short description: The Deodhar Trophy is a List A cricket competition in Indian domestic cricket. It is named after Prof. D. B. Deodhar (known as the Grand Old Man of Indian cricket) and is a 50-over knockout competition played on an annual basis among the 3 national level teams - India A, India B and India C.

Title: Syed Mustaq ali tournament
Short description: The Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy is a Twenty20 cricket domestic championship in India, organized by Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI), among the teams from Ranji Trophy. The 2008-09 season was the inaugural season for this trophy.

Title: Duleep Trophy
Short description: The Duleep Trophy is a domestic first-class cricket competition played in India. Named after Kumar Shri Duleepsinhji of Nawanagar (also known as 'Duleep'), the competition was originally contested by teams representing geographical zones of India.

Title: Justin Langer
Short description: Justin Lee Langer AM is an Australian former cricketer and the current coach of the Australian national men’s cricket team, having been appointed to the role in May 2018. A left-handed batsman, Langer is best known for his partnership with Matthew Hayden as Australia's test opening batsmen during the early and mid-2000s, considered one of the most successful ever.
Image caption: Justin Langer, Sydney Cricket Ground, 2 January 2007.

Title: Yuvraj singh
Short description: Yuvraj Singh (born 12 December 1981) is an Indian international cricketer, who plays all forms of the game. An all-rounder who bats left-handed in the middle order and bowls slow left-arm orthodox, Yuvraj is the son of former Indian fast bowler and Punjabi actor Yograj Singh.
Image caption: Yuvraj Singh appointed as Ulysse Nardin watch brand ambassador

Title: Tillakaratne Dilshan
Short description: Tillakaratne Mudiyanselage Dilshan is a former Sri Lankan cricketer and former captain of the Sri Lanka national cricket team. As the best rated Sri Lankan player in run-chases in ODI history, he is often regarded as one of the most innovative batsmen of all time.

Title: Zaheer Khan
Short description: Zaheer Khan is an Indian former cricketer who played all forms of the game for the Indian national team from 2000 till 2014. He was the second-most successful Indian pace bowler in Test cricket, behind Kapil Dev.

Title: Shahid Afridi
Short description: Sahibzada Mohammad Shahid Khan Afridi, popularly known as Boom Boom, is a Pakistani cricketer and former captain of the Pakistan national cricket team. As a successful all-rounder, Afridi was respected for his consistent bowling that relies on change of pace rather than spin, but drew greater attention for his aggressive batting style.

Title: Shane Watson
Short description: Shane Robert Watson is an Australian international cricketer who has played for Australia’s national cricket team and currently plays for Chennai Super Kings in the Indian Premier League and Quetta Gladiators in the Pakistan Super League respectively.

Title: Shaun Marsh
Short description: Shaun Edward Marsh is an Australian cricketer who plays for the Western Warriors in Australian domestic cricket and represents Australia in Test and One Day International formats. Nicknamed SOS ("Son of Swampy"), he is a left-handed opening batsman.

Title: Sohail Tanvir
Short description: Sohail Tanvir is a Pakistani cricketer, who has gained repute for his unorthodox left arm bowling action and particularly for the success it has gained him in the Twenty20 format of the game.

Title: Pragyan Ojha
Short description: Pragyan Prayash Ojha is an Indian cricketer, who has represented India in Test, ODIs and T20. He is an attacking slow left arm orthodox bowler and left-hand tail-ender batsman.

Title: Robin Uthappa
Short description: Robin Venu Uthappa is an Indian cricketer. He plays for Karnataka in domestic cricket and Kolkata Knight Riders in the IPL.

Title: Matthew hayden
Short description: Matthew Lawrence Hayden AM is an Australian cricket commentator and former cricketer. His career spanned fifteen years. Hayden was a powerful and aggressive left-handed opening batsman, known for his ability to score quickly at both Test and one day levels.

Title: Adam Gilchrist
Short description: Adam Craig Gilchrist, AM nicknamed "Gilly" or "Churchy", is an Australian cricket commentator and former international cricketer and former captain of Australia. He was an attacking left-handed batsman and record-breaking wicket-keeper, who redefined the role for the Australia national team through his aggressive batting.

Title: Trent Boult
Short description: Trent Alexander Boult is a New Zealand international cricketer who plays as a bowler for Northern Districts in New Zealand's domestic cricket, and New Zealand internationally.

Title: Martin Guptil
Short description: Martin James Guptil is a New Zealand international cricketer who plays as an opening batsman in limited overs formats of the game. Guptill is the first cricketer from New Zealand and the fifth overall to have scored a double century in a One Day International match.

Title: Mitchell Starc
Short description: Mitchell Aaron Starc, is an Australian international cricketer who plays for the Australian national team and New South Wales in domestic cricket. He is a left-arm fast bowler and a capable lower order left-handed batsman.

Title: Floyd Reifer
Short description: Floyd Lamonte Reifer is a Barbadian cricketer. He is a left-handed middle-order batsman and a right-arm medium pace bowler. Reifer has played six Tests and eight One Day Internationals for the West Indies cricket team, spread over a home tour against Sri Lanka in 1997 and the 2009 edition of the ICC Champions trophy.

Title: Martin Crowe
Short description: Martin David Crowe MBE was a New Zealand former cricketer, Test and ODI captain as well as a commentator. He played for the New Zealand national cricket team between 1982 and 1995, and is regarded as the country's greatest batsman.
Image caption: Martin Crowe batting in a charity match in 2011

Title: Lance klusner
Short description: Lance Klusener is a former South African all-rounder cricketer. He is known for his aggressive batting and his fast-medium swing bowling. He is nicknamed "Zulu" because of his fluency in the Zulu language. Since his retirement he has occasionally commentated on cricket in both Zulu and Xhosa.

Title: geoff Allott
Short description: Geoffrey Ian Allott  is a former New Zealand cricketer who played in 10 Tests and 31 One Day Internationals from 1996 to 2000. He retired from all cricket in 2001, following series of injuries.

Title: Mickey Arthur
Short description: John Michael "Mickey" Arthur is a South African cricket coach and former cricketer, who played in South African domestic cricket from 1986 to 2001. He is the current coach of the Pakistan Cricket Team.

Title: Ottis Gibson
Short description: Ottis Delroy Gibson is a former West Indian player from Barbados. A pace bowler and exploiter of the older cricket ball for the West Indies, Gibson is now the head coach of the South African cricket team.

Title: Gary Stead
Short description: Gary Raymond Stead is a former New Zealand Test cricketer who is the head coach of the New Zealand cricket team, having been appointed in August 2018. A top-order batsman, Stead played five Tests in nine months in 1999, averaging 34.75 and never being dismissed in single figures.

Title: Shane Warne
Short description: Shane Keith Warne is an Australian cricket commentator and former cricketer, and ODI captain of the Australian national team. Widely regarded as one of the greatest bowlers in the history of the game, Warne was named one of the Wisden Cricketers of the Year in the 1994 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.

Title: Ricky Ponting
Short description: Ricky Thomas Ponting, AO, is an Australian cricket commentator and former cricketer, and two-time World Cup winning captain in 2003 and 2007, widely regarded as one of the greatest batsmen of all time. Ponting was captain of the Australian national team during its 'golden era'; between 2004 and 2011 in Tests and 2002 and 2011 in One Day Internationals.

Title: Trevor Bayliss
Short description: Trevor Harley Bayliss is an Australian cricket coach and former first class cricketer. He played for New South Wales between 1985 and 1997 before becoming a coach. Bayliss is currently coach of England. He coached Sri Lanka between 2007 and 2011, a period which culminated in his team finishing as runners-up in the 2011 World Cup.

Title: Imran khan
Short description: Imran Ahmed Khan Niazi HI PP is a Pakistani politician and former international cricketer who is the 22nd and incumbent Prime Minister of Pakistan.

Title: Chaminda Vaas
Short description: Warnakulasuriya Patabendige Ushantha Joseph Chaminda Vaas, more widely known as Chaminda Vaas, is a former Sri Lankan international cricketer, who played all forms of the game, and a former ODI captain. Often described as the 'most penetrative and successful new-ball bowler Sri Lanka has produced' Vaas currently holds the record for the best bowling figure in ODI history, and only bowler to take an 8 wicket-haul in ODIs.

Title: Sunil Narine
Short description: Sunil Philip Narine is a Trinidadian cricketer of Indian descent who plays for the West Indies. Primarily an off-spin bowler, he is also an aggressive left-handed batsman.

Title: Javed Miandad
Short description: Mohammad Javed Miandad, popularly known as Javed Miandad, is a Pakistani cricket coach, commentator and former cricketer known for his unconventional style of captaincy and batting.

Title: Inzamam ul Haq
Short description: Syed Inzamam-ul-Haq, also known as Inzi, is a former Pakistani cricketer, and former captain.

Title: Allan Donald
Short description: Allan Anthony Donald is a former South African cricketer who is now a cricket coach. Often nicknamed 'White Lightning', he is considered as one of the South Africa national cricket team's most successful pace bowlers.

Title: Jacques Kallis
Short description: Jacques Kallis is a former South African cricketer, and, a former Test and ODI captain. As a right-handed batsman and right-arm fast-medium swing bowler, Kallis is regarded as one of the greatest cricketers of all time and the game's greatest all rounder.

Title: Brendon McCullum
Short description: Brendon Barrie "Baz" McCullum, ONZM is a former New Zealand international cricketer, who played all formats, and also a former captain in all forms. McCullum took quick scoring to Test matches as well, notably recording the fastest test century of all time. He is considered as one of the most successful batsmen and captains of New Zealand cricket.

Title: Sanath Jayasuriya
Short description: Deshabandu Sanath Teran Jayasuriya is a former Sri Lankan cricketer and a former captain of the Sri Lankan national team. Considered one of the greatest One Day International (ODI) players of all time, Jayasuriya is well known for his powerful striking and match winning all-round performances in ODI cricket.

Title: Muttaiah Muralitharan
Short description: Deshabandu Muttiah Muralitharan is a former Sri Lankan cricketer who was rated the greatest Test match bowler ever by Wisden Cricketers' Almanack in 2002.

Title: Arjuna Ranatunga
Short description: Deshamanya Arjuna Ranatunga is a former Sri Lankan cricketer and 1996 Cricket World Cup winning captain for Sri Lanka. Often nicknamed as Captain Cool, he is regarded as the pioneer to lift Sri Lankan cricket from underdog status to one of great forces in cricketing world. Ranatunga started his political career in 2005, and now currently is the cabinet minister of Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation.

Title: Kumar Sangakkara
Short description: Kumar Sangakkara is a Sri Lankan cricket commentator and former cricketer and captain of the Sri Lankan national team. He is widely regarded as one of the world's most influential cricketers and one of the greatest batsmen of all-time.

Title: Clive Lloyd
Short description: Clive Hubert Lloyd CBE AO is a former West Indies cricketer. In 1971 he was named Wisden Cricketer of the Year. He captained the West Indies between 1974 and 1985 and oversaw their rise to become the dominant Test-playing nation.

Title: Curtly Ambrose
Short description: Sir Curtly Elconn Lynwall Ambrose, KCN is a former cricketer from Antigua who played 98 Test matches for the West Indies. A fast bowler, he took 405 Test wickets at an average of 20.99 and topped the ICC Player Rankings for much of his career to be rated the best bowler in the world.

Title: Viv Richards
Short description: Sir Isaac Vivian Alexander Richards, KNH, OBE, known as Viv Richards, is an Antiguan former cricketer, who represented the West Indies at Test and international levels. He is regarded as one of the greatest batsmen of all time.

Title: Waqar Younis
Short description: Waqar Younis is a Pakistani Australian cricket coach, commentator and former cricketer who captained Pakistan national cricket team. A right-arm fast bowler, Waqar is regarded as one of the greatest bowlers of all time. He is also the former coach of the Pakistani cricket team.

Title: Brian lara
Short description: Brian Charles Lara, TC, OCC, AM is a Trinidadian former international cricketer, widely acknowledged as one of the greatest batsmen of all time. He topped the Test batting rankings on several occasions and holds several cricketing records.

Title: Graham Gooch
Short description: Graham Alan Gooch, OBE, DL is a former English first-class cricketer who captained Essex and England. He was one of the most successful international batsmen of his generation, and through a career spanning from 1973 until 2000, he became the most prolific run scorer of all time, with 67,057 runs across first-class and limited-overs games.

Title: Andre russel
Short description: Andre Dwayne Russell is a Jamaican cricketer. Russell plays for the West Indies internationally and for Jamaica in West Indian domestic cricket, as an all-rounder. He bats predominantly in the middle order for the West Indies. Widely regarded as one of the most powerful strikers of the cricket ball, Russell scored a century in a record 40 balls in the 2018 Caribbean Premier League against Trinbago Knight Riders.

Title: Dwayne Bravo
Short description: Dwayne John Bravo is a former Trinidadian cricketer, who played all formats of the game and a former captain of West Indies in all formats and plays league cricket for Chennai Super Kings & Quetta Gladiators. A genuine all-rounder, Bravo bats right-handed and bowls right-arm medium-fast pace.

Title: Glenn Maxwell
Short description: Glenn James Maxwell is an Australian international cricketer, who currently plays ODI and Twenty20 cricket for Australia. He has also played Test cricket for Australia. He represents Victoria and Melbourne Stars in Australian domestic cricket and Lancashire County Cricket Club in English County Cricket.

Title: Mohit Sharma
Short description: Mohit Mahipal Sharma (born 18 September 1988) is an Indian cricketer who plays for Haryana. He is a right-arm medium-fast bowler.

Title: Mike Hussey
Short description: Michael Edward Killeen Hussey (born 27 May 1975) also known as Mike Hussey is an Australian cricket coach, commentator and former international cricketer, who played all forms of the game. Hussey is also widely known by his nickname 'Mr Cricket'.
Image caption: Mike Hussey at a training session at the en:Adelaide Oval

Title: Nathan Astle
Short description: Nathan John Astle MNZM (born 15 September 1971) is a former New Zealand cricketer, who played all formats of the game.

Title: Ross Taylor
Short description: Luteru Ross Poutoa Lote Taylor (born 8 March 1984) is a New Zealand cricketer, who plays predominantly at number four in all formats of the game. Taylor is considered as one of the greatest batsmen to represent New Zealand
Image caption: Ross Taylor, India Vs New zealand One day International, 10 December 2010

Title: David Gower
Short description: David Ivon Gower OBE (born 1 April 1957) is a British cricket commentator and former cricketer who was captain of the England cricket team during the 1980s. Described as one of the most stylish left-handed batsmen of his era, Gower played 117 Test matches and 114 One Day Internationals (ODI)
Image caption: at Sydney Cricket Ground, Australia, c.2007.

Title: Roger Binny
Short description: Roger Michael Humphrey Binny (born 19 July 1955) is an Indian former cricketer. He played 27 tests and 72 ODIs for India.
Image caption: Roger Binny in 2018 at British Library, Bangalore

Title: Gordon Greenidge
Short description: Cuthbert Gordon Greenidge MBE (born 1 May 1951)[1] is a Barbadian former first-class cricketer, who played Tests and One Day Internationals for 17 years for West Indies.

Title: Mike Hendrick
Short description: Michael Hendrick (born 22 October 1948) is a former English cricketer, who played in thirty Tests and twenty two ODIs for England from 1973 to 1981. He played for Derbyshire from 1969 to 1981, and for Nottinghamshire from 1982 to 1984.

Title: Glenn Turner
Short description: Glenn Maitland Turner (born 26 May 1947) played cricket for New Zealand and was one of the country's best and most prolific batsmen. He is the current head of the New Zealand Cricket selection panel.

Title: Gary Gilmour
Short description: Gary "Gus" John Gilmour (26 June 1951 – 10 June 2014) was an Australian cricketer who played in 15 Tests and 5 One Day Internationals (ODIs) between 1973 and 1977.

Title: Andrew flintoff
Image caption: Andrew Flintoff after training at Adelaide Oval

Title: Joe Root
Short description: Joseph Edward Root (born 30 December 1990) is an English international cricketer who is the current captain of the England Test team. He also represents Yorkshire domestically. He is often regarded as one of the best batsmen in the world.
Image caption: Joe Root in training in Australia

Title: Kevin Pietersen
Short description: Kevin Peter Pietersen MBE (born 27 June 1980) is a former English cricketer. He is a right-handed batsman and occasional off spin bowler who played in all three formats for England between 2005 and 2014.

Title: Kyle Mills
Short description: Kyle David Mills (born 15 March 1979) is a former New Zealand international cricketer who captained the New Zealand cricket team in limited overs matches. Mills played top-class cricket between 1998 and 2015 as an all-rounder.

Title: Andrew Tye
Short description: Andrew James Tye (born 12 December 1986) is an Australian cricketer who plays One Day Internationals (ODIs) and Twenty20 Internationals (T20Is) for the Australian national cricket team. He is most famous for his use of the knuckle ball and wide variation of pace.

Title: Suresh Raina
Short description: Suresh Kumar Raina (born 27 November 1986) is an Indian international cricketer. An aggressive left-handed middle-order batsman and an occasional off-spin bowler, he is also regarded as one of the best fielders in world cricket.

Title: Steve Smith
Short description: Steven Peter Devereux Smith (born 2 June 1989) is an Australian international cricketer and former captain of the Australian national team. On 30 December 2017, he reached a Test batting rating of 947, the second-highest of all time

Title: Ravichandran Ashwin
Short description: Ravichandran Ashwin (About this soundpronunciation (help·info); born 17 September 1986) is an Indian international cricketer. A Bowler who bats right-handed and bowls right-arm off break, Ashwin plays for Tamil Nadu in domestic cricket and captains Kings XI Punjab in the Indian Premier League
Image caption: Ravichandran Ashwin receives an award from VVS Laxman at the 2014 CEAT Cricket Ratings Award.

Title: Prithvi Shaw
Short description: Prithvi Pankaj Shaw (born 9 November 1999) is an Indian cricketer and former India national under-19 cricket team captain.

Title: Rishab Pant
Short description: Rishabh Rajendra Pant (born 4 October 1997) is a professional Indian cricketer who plays for India, Delhi, and the Delhi Capitals.[2] In December 2015, he was named in India's squad for the 2016 Under-19 Cricket World Cup

Title: Shreyas Iyer
Short description: Shreyas Santosh Iyer (born 6 December 1994) is an Indian cricketer who presently captains Delhi Capitals in the Indian Premier League. A right-handed top-order batsman, Iyer has played One Day Internationals and Twenty20 Internationals for the India national cricket team.

Title: Bogra
Short description: Bogra, officially known as Bogura, is a major city located in the Bogra District, Rajshahi Division, Bangladesh. It is major commercial hub.Bogra is named after Nasiruddin Bughra Khan, the Governor of Bengal from 1279 to 1282

Title: Galle
Short description: Galle (formerly Point de Galle) is a major city in Sri Lanka, situated on the southwestern tip, 119 km from Colombo.Galle is the best example of a fortified city built by the Portuguese in South and Southeast Asia, showing the interaction between Portuguese architectural styles and native traditions.

Title: Nangarhar
Short description: Nangarhār also called Nangrahar or Ningrahar, is one of the 34 provinces of Afghanistan, located in the eastern part of the country. It is divided into twenty-two districts and has a population of about 1,436,000.
Image caption: Branches of the Kunar River meet with the Kabul River in Nangarhar

Title: Sialkot
Short description: Sialkot is a city in Punjab, Pakistan. It is located in north-east Punjab — one of Pakistan's most industrialised regions.
Image caption: Jagannath Temple in Sialkot is dedicated to the Hindu God Jagannath.

Title: Ayodhya
Short description: Ayodhya is a city located in Faizabad district of Uttar Pradesh. The city is identified with the legendary city of Ayodhya, and as such, is the birthplace of Rama and setting of the epic Ramayana.
Image caption: The ‘Kanak Bhawan’ is the one of the most importantemples in Ayodhya dedicated to Lord Ram and his divine consort Sita.

Title: Johannesburg
Short description: Johannesburg (also known as Jozi, Jo'burg, and eGoli) is the largest city in South Africa and one of the 50 largest urban areas in the world.

Title: West Indies
Short description:
The West Indies is a region of the North Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean that includes the island countries and surrounding waters of three major archipelagos: the Greater Antilles, the Lesser Antilles, and the Lucayan Archipelago.[1]

The region includes all the islands in or bordering the Caribbean Sea, plus The Bahamas and the Turks and Caicos Islands, which are in the Atlantic Ocean. Depending on the context, some references to the West Indies may include some nations of northern South America that share the history and culture of the West Indian islands.
